comments.body: Are these being or have they been sent upstream?
All of them are backported fixes, either from squash itself or upstream libraries (i.e.: from zlib, zpaq, etc).
Could you please remind me why this is Linux only?

It wasn't at first, but then I noticed the only recipe that uses `lzo` is `pytables` and uses `[linux]` selector. Then noticed that the `osx-64` package is actually empty:

```
$ curl -L https://anaconda.org/anaconda/lzo/2.06/download/osx-64/lzo-2.06-0.tar.bz2 | tar jtvf -
-rw-r--r--  0 ilan   admin       0 Sep 11  2012 .index/lzo-2.06-0
-rw-r--r--  0 ilan   admin      18 Sep 11  2012 info/files
-rw-r--r--  0 ilan   admin       0 Sep 11  2012 info/has_prefix
-rw-r--r--  0 ilan   admin     142 Sep 11  2012 info/index.json
-rw-r--r--  0 ilan   admin     159 Sep 11  2012 info/meta
```

As far I can tell from the build logs, `pytables` builds without `lzo` support and `squash` uses the vendored `lzo` code. 

I have no idea why the `lzo` package is empty for `osx-64`. But stating that we only use it for `linux` seems a good thing to me.

That's not great. Guessing `lzo` comes from `defaults`. We should probably let them know.

Though it might be good for us to get our own `lzo` package as well.

xref: https://github.com/conda-forge/staged-recipes/issues/2428
